>>27738740
It sounds like the workload is just too much for you right now. I was similar in my second year, especially because it was 2020 and I'm the sort of person who benefits from face-to-face teaching. I was taking a full course load, 4 units a semester, and dropped down to 3, since that's the lowest you can go without going part-time. It really helped me, I had more free time, I was more on top of and aware of when things were due. I was just too used to high school, where they spoonfeed you and constantly remind you about stuff, and was totally unprepared for how much self-motivation was needed. I got a 93 on an essay for one class and an overall 67 in the class because the weighting on weekly quizzes and class participation (two things I definitely did not do) was so high. Can you drop down to even one less unit? It will make your degree a bit longer, I went a semester longer than I should have and it delayed my masters plans by a full year since I want to start with the rest of the cohort, but it was worth it. If I hadn't made the call to reduce my workload, I'm not sure I would have finished, or would have finished with much worse grades than I did.

As an employer, I can assure you that it is not. An employer may ask about it, to determine if it should be a red flag or not, but most won't because the job is entry level and there's people in their 60s and 70s getting degrees no one will look twice at a 25 year old.

Employers don't care about your degree. Your degree no longer tells an employer much, if anything, about your knowledge, skills, personality or general capabilities because they're all paper mills now.

A hiring manager cares much more about past experience, references, that kind of thing because those give much more information about a candidate.

Unless you're trying to be hired as a diversity hire, telling an employer that you had to take longer to finish uni because you got run over WILL be a red flag because a hiring manager will hear that as "I'm low capacity, low productivity, low capability". Don't lie to a hiring manager, but unless it's obvious that you're disabled or you need special adjustments because of your disability, if they don't ask, don't tell.
